summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and attorneys from Blackfords LLP representing Prince Andrew, the Duke of York. It details the breakdown of negotiations for a voluntary interview, with the U.S. prosecutors seeking a live interview and the Duke's legal team offering only a written witness statement and written Q&A, limited to topics relevant to the Ghislaine Maxwell indictment. The U.S. side ultimately states they will proceed with a compelled interview request via the UK Central Authority.

keyFacts: Prince Andrew, the Duke of York, through his lawyers, declined to participate in a voluntary live interview (in-person or video) with U.S. prosecutors, offering only a written witness statement and written answers to questions.

The Duke's legal team sought to limit the scope of questioning to the period of the Ghislaine Maxwell indictment (1994-1997), while U.S. prosecutors sought information on 'the full range of topics' relevant to their ongoing investigation.
The U.S. Attorney's Office stated they regarded the Duke of York not as a witness but as a 'subject' of their investigation, a point of contention raised by his lawyers.

The negotiations broke down, leading the U.S. to announce on September 23, 2020, their intention to proceed with a formal Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request to compel an interview of the Duke of York.
The Duke's attorneys demanded strict confidentiality assurances, that any information provided would only be used for the Maxwell prosecution and not shared with complainants or in civil matters.
